For an LDP mechanism 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}, its worst-case variance is denoted by V𝒜subscript𝑉𝒜V_{\mathcal{A}}. We obtain this table based on results of [8].

references: Proposing new LDP mechanisms. Based on results of [8], Table I on Page I shows that among the three mechanisms Duchi, Laplace, and PM, in terms of the worst-case variance, Duchi is the best for 0<ϵ<1.290italic-ϵ1.290<\epsilon<1.29, while PM is the best for ϵ>1.29italic-ϵ1.29\epsilon>1.29. Then a natural research question is that can we propose better or even optimal LDP mechanisms? The optimal LDP mechanism for numeric data is still open in the literature, but the optimal LDP mechanism for categorical data has been discussed by Kairouz et al. [12]. In particular, [12] shows that for a categorical attribute (with a limited number of discrete values), the binary and randomized response mechanisms, are universally optimal for very small and large ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon, respectively. Although [12] handles categorical data, its results can provide the following insight even for continuous numeric data: for very small ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon, a mechanism generating a binary output should be optimal; for very large ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon, the optimal mechanism’s output should have infinite possibilities. This is also in consistent with the results of Table I on Page I. Based on the above insight, intuitively, there may exist a range of medium ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon where a mechanism with three, or four, or five, … output possibilities can be optimal. To this end, our first motivation of proposing new LDP mechanisms is to develop a mechanism with three output possibilities such that the mechanism outperform existing mechanisms of Table I for some ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon. The outcome of the above motivation is our mechanism called Three-Outputs. Since the analysis of Three-Outputs is already very complex, we do not consider a mechanism with four, or five, … output possibilities.

Table II on Page II gives a comparison of our and existing LDP mechanisms. For simplicity, we do not include Laplace in the comparison since Laplace is worse than PM for any ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon according to Table I. As shown in Table II, in terms of the worst-case variance for a single numeric attribute with a domain [−1,1]11[-1,1], Three-Outputs outperforms Duchi for ϵ>ln⁡2≈0.69italic-ϵ20.69\epsilon>\ln 2\approx 0.69 (and is the same as Duchi for ϵ≤ln⁡2italic-ϵ2\epsilon\leq\ln 2), while PM-SUB beats PM for any ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon; moreover, Three-Outputs outperforms both Duchi and PM for ln⁡2<ϵ<3.272italic-ϵ3.27\ln 2<\epsilon<3.27, while PM-SUB beats both Duchi and PM for ϵ>1.19italic-ϵ1.19\epsilon>1.19.

Three-Outputs and PM-SUB are our main LDP mechanisms proposed in this paper. The results in this table show the advantages of our mechanisms over existing mechanisms for a wide range of privacy parameter ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon.

references: Table II on Page II gives a comparison of our and existing LDP mechanisms. For simplicity, we do not include Laplace in the comparison since Laplace is worse than PM for any ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon according to Table I. As shown in Table II, in terms of the worst-case variance for a single numeric attribute with a domain [−1,1]11[-1,1], Three-Outputs outperforms Duchi for ϵ>ln⁡2≈0.69italic-ϵ20.69\epsilon>\ln 2\approx 0.69 (and is the same as Duchi for ϵ≤ln⁡2italic-ϵ2\epsilon\leq\ln 2), while PM-SUB beats PM for any ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon; moreover, Three-Outputs outperforms both Duchi and PM for ln⁡2<ϵ<3.272italic-ϵ3.27\ln 2<\epsilon<3.27, while PM-SUB beats both Duchi and PM for ϵ>1.19italic-ϵ1.19\epsilon>1.19.

Using the LDP-FedSGD algorithm for federated learning in IoV as a motivating context, we present novel LDP mechanisms for numeric data with a continuous domain. Among our proposed mechanisms, Three-Outputs and PM-SUB outperform existing mechanisms for a wide range of ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon, as shown in the theoretical results in Table II and confirmed by experiments. In terms of comparing our Three-Outputs and PM-SUB, we have: Three-Outputs, whose output has three possibilities, is better for small ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon, while PM-SUB, whose output can take infinite possibilities of an interval, has higher utility for large ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon. Our PM-SUB is a slightly suboptimal version of our PM-OPT to simplify the expressions. We further combine Three-Outputs and PM-SUB to obtain a hybrid mechanism HM-TP, which achieves even higher utility.

S3.T3.caption: TABLE III: We compare different privacy notions in this table. In this paper, we focus on ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-local differential privacy which achieves user-level privacy protection with distributed perturbation (ULDP). We do not consider record-level privacy protection with distributed perturbation (RLDP) which implements perturbation at each user via standard differential privacy, since we aim to achieve user-level privacy protection instead of the weaker record-level privacy protection (a vehicle is a user in our IoV applications and may have multiple records). We also do not investigate record/user-level privacy protection with centralized perturbation (RLCP/ULCP) since this paper considers a honest-but-curious aggregator instead of a trusted aggregator.

In the case of distributed perturbation, when all users set the same privacy parameter ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon, we refer to ULDP and RLDP above as ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-ULDP and ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-RLDP, respectively. Table III presents a comparison of ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-ULDP, ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-RLDP, ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-RLCP, and
ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-ULCP. In this paper’s focus, each user applies ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-local differential privacy, so our framework is under ULDP. The reasons that we consider ULDP instead of RLDP, RLCP, and ULCP are as follows.
